itinerary.activity: Welcome and Introduction: Begin by greeting the group and introducing yourself as an Art History major. Share the name of the exhibit, 'Objectifying China,' and explain that the tour will explore the artistry, techniques, and cultural significance of Chinese ceramics across different dynasties. Highlight the focus on Qing dynasty pieces, the color green, and ceramic techniques to connect with their interests.

Context of Qingbai Wares: Discuss the origins of Qingbai wares during the Northern Song dynasty, emphasizing their icy blue-green glaze and innovative underglaze decoration techniques. Show an example of a Qingbai piece (if available) and explain how the scrolling floral patterns were inspired by metalwork and lacquer designs of the time. Engage students by asking them to describe the color and patterns they see.

Exploration of Qing Dynasty Celadon: Introduce the decline of Longquan kilns and the revival of celadon during the Kangxi and Yongzheng reigns. Highlight the innovation of delicate celadon tones by reducing iron content. Use the Kangxi vase example to explain how imperial tastes influenced ceramic production. Encourage students to imagine how these pieces might have been used or displayed in the imperial court.

Hands-On Engagement: Discuss the introduction of translucent green enamel during the Qing dynasty and its popularity in both Chinese and European courts. Show an example of famille verte porcelain (if available) and ask students to identify the green elements and other colors in the design. Provide a brief activity where students sketch their own ceramic designs inspired by the swirling waves and auspicious emblems.

Personal Reflection: Share your perspective as an Art History major on the significance of techniques like underglaze decoration and the use of green enamel. Reflect on how these innovations demonstrate the fusion of artistry and technical skill in Chinese ceramics. Invite students to share their thoughts on what they found most interesting or surprising during the tour.

Wrap-Up and Conclusion: Summarize the key points covered during the tour, including the evolution of ceramic techniques, the role of imperial patronage, and the cultural significance of colors like green. Thank the students for their participation and encourage them to explore more about Chinese history and art on their own. Provide a moment for final questions or comments.
